article.description:
Larry House scored a career-high 23 points
and had eight rebounds as No. 10 Creighton beat Illinois State
95-82 Monday night.
article.headline: House scores career-high 23 points in win
article.linkText: House delivers to help Creighton defeat Illinois State
article.story: OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- Creighton's Larry House took it as an insult when Illinois State's defensive strategy allowed him to roam free while the Redbirds tried to shut down star forward Kyle Korver. House had career highs of 23 points and eight rebounds, and the (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today, No. 10 AP) Bluejays beat Illinois State 95-82 on Monday night. "When teams play off me, it kind of upsets me because I feel like I'm a player,'' House said. "It kind of hurt my feelings, to tell you the truth. So I wanted to make them pay for that.'' House, who came in averaging 9.1 points, shot 8-of-12 on a night when Korver was held in check most of the game. Korver still finished with 17 points after being limited to five shots and 12 points through the first 30 minutes. The Bluejays (16-1, 7-0 Missouri Valley Conference) won their sixth straight. But they were disappointed with their effort, which came just hours after they earned a Top 10 ranking for the first time in the 85-year history of the program. Illinois State (1-14, 0-7) scored the most points of any Creighton opponent this season, and the Redbirds did it by shooting 53.6 percent. Before Monday, no team had shot better than 50 percent against the Bluejays. "I don't think when I came here as a freshman that people thought being ranked in the Top 10 was really possible,'' Korver said. "I don't really know if we deserve that right now.'' Joe Dabbert added 11 points and Mike Grimes 10 for the Bluejays. Trey Guidry led Illinois State with 21 points, and Baboucarr Bojang had 18 as the Redbirds dropped their eighth in a row. The Bluejays had a 40-9 advantage in bench scoring and got 31 points off the Redbirds' 20 turnovers. "Obviously, Creighton thrives on turning you over and generating offense with their defense,'' Illinois State coach Tom Richardson said. "We had some self-inflicted wounds out there that we needed to avoid.'' House bested his previous career high of 20 points against Northern Iowa on Dec. 4. His dunk finished a 10-0 run and gave the Bluejays a 22-10 lead midway through the first half. Guidry hit back-to-back 3s as Illinois State pulled to 34-30, but DeAnthony Bowden made a 3 and Michael Lindeman and Grimes scored in succession to stretch the Bluejays' advantage to 41-30. The Bluejays led by as many as 23 points midway through the second half. Marcus Arnold, the Redbirds' leading scorer in conference play, fouled out with 8:13 left after scoring 12 points. "We didn't have that same spark out there,'' Korver said. "Larry played really, really well. Some of the rest of us were going through the motions, it seemed like.''
